Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Research Experiences in Big Data and Machine/Deep Learning for Oklahoma STEM Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: As artificial intelligence continues to transform society, a skilled STEM workforce is becoming more critical for the growth and diversification of science, innovation, and the U.S. economy. This RET site at Oklahoma State University (OSU) will immerse high school teachers in research and curricular development activities to better engage students with AI topics like Big Data, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning. OSU will leverage an existing partnership with the Tulsa Regional STEM Alliance to recruit teachers to the site while simultaneously strengthening and creating relationships between industry, high schools, community colleges, and universities. This RET Site will also provide opportunities for high school and community college students to continue engaging in research after the RET program has run its course, further promoting opportunities to propel the next generation of technologically saavy students into computing careers. <br/><br/>Oklahoma State University (OSU) in partnership with Tulsa Regional STEM Alliance (TRSA) propose a RET site to conduct research and develop curriculum for Big Data and Machine Learning/Deep Learning (ML/DL) to equip teachers and engage students to achieve a computing aware and capable workforce. The program will recruit ten teachers from the Tulsa and surrounding areas to conduct research and curriculum development activities at the OSU campus in Tulsa for six weeks during the summer. The RET site will include ML/DL projects that call on large datasets in different areas. The teachers, faculty mentors along with the curriculum coordinators will develop learning experiences, activities, problems and examples suitable for use in their classrooms. The objectives of the program are: 1). Develop teachersâ€™ knowledge of ML/DL/Big Data. 2). Develop and implement innovative curriculum by translating research experiences into classroom practices. 3). Build long-term, sustainable relationships between OSU, TRSA, Community colleges, high schools districts and industry to promote and provide support for advancing STEM education.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the second and final year of this program, we conducted a 6-week long summer research training with 12 high school and middle school teachers. One group of 3 teachers presented a poster in the NSF RET Virtual Poster Session. We have also strengthen our connections with CHSI (an industry partner) and cultivated new relationships with Paycom. Out of these 12 teachers, 7 teachers across different educational levels actively cultivated practical skills, critical thinking, and enthusiasm for machine learning and artificial intelligence, underscoring a dedicated commitment to making these advanced concepts accessible and impactful for students: 

 

Ihsan Gokalp, supervised by Dr. Jahan Sharmin at Dove Science Academy / OSU, focused on Machine Learning and Deep Learning. Conducting a 4-week module for a well-performing section of the 8th-grade class, Gokalp covered machine learning basics, introduced Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and engaged students in practical projects like "Image classification with Google Coral." The module aimed to explore real-world applications of machine learning, fostering independent exploration.


Under the guidance of Dr. Arun Bagavathi, Delavita John focused on integrating machine learning into the high school curriculum. Delavita initiated a Coding Club, with a gender representation of 2 girls and 4 boys, aiming to enhance students' decision-making skills based on data. The integration strategy involved creating modules and practical applications with DistillBERT and BERT models. Positive shifts in students' knowledge levels were observed.

 

Ufuk Caliskan, supervised by Dr. Shamsuddin, led an Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Club for students in grades 6th through 9th. The club emphasized hands-on learning, theoretical exploration, and real-world applications, using platforms like Code.org's AI Lab. Practical projects, discussions on bias in machine learning, and shared personal experiences contribute to a dynamic learning environment.

 

Supervised by Dr. Shamsuddin at Dove Schools of Discovery, Mustafa Kont conducted an extracurricular activity on "Machine Learning with Python and Diabetes." The activity aimed to introduce students to machine learning techniques using Python, focusing on diabetes prediction and management. The success was measured through pre and post-event evaluations, highlighting participants' improved proficiency in Python and hands-on experience in preprocessing healthcare datasets.

Under the supervision of Dr. Johnson Thomas, Mike Jones at Berryhill High School introduced machine learning using Python and Google Colab to 33 students. The project, focusing on a Diabetes dataset, covered the basics, data preprocessing, building ML models, and creating explainers using LIME. Positive outcomes were observed in students' knowledge and skills, aligning education with real-world applications.

 

MacKenzie Lance Jones, supervised by Dr. Bagavathi, integrated machine learning into the AP Statistics curriculum. The project focused on experimental design, data collection, and creating machine learning models. Utilizing public datasets and addressing ethical considerations, Jones witnessed a positive impact on students' skills and increased interest in the course.

 

Rouchelle Major aimed to create a Data Science and Machine Learning unit for Forensics classes. Integrated into class time, the program covered Python basics, data preprocessing, machine learning, and ethical discussions. Positive shifts in students' knowledge and comfort levels were noted, with 66 students expressing a desire for more projects in the future.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/12/2024
Modified by: Rittika Shamsuddin
